metadata.sermon_title: Living in the House of Deep Shalom
metadata.bible_text: Psalm 90 (with references to 1 Thessalonians 2 and the Great Commandment)
metadata.sermon_start_end: At the beginning of Psalm 90, it is as though the speaker, in great reflective maturity, has finally arrived at an awesome, sure rest point in his life: Lord, you have been our dwelling place in all generations. [...] In confidence the Psalmist prays for us as we do our work: Let the favor of the Lord our God be upon us.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: While Psalm 90 is the primary text, the sermon fails Dekker's requirement of specificity. It treats the Psalm as a launchpad for general themes of 'shalom' and 'dialogue.' It lacks the 'point that can be found nowhere else.' By the third section, it drifts into a topical speech about the Great Commandment and Paul's letters, diluting the unique voice of the Psalm.
quotes: In generic terms, the Gospel reading characterizes the work we have to do...
The gospel shared is the news that the creator God wants us all—liberals and conservatives...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus exclusively on the unique tension in Psalm 90 between God’s eternity and human transience without retreating into the 'generic' Gospel reading.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of the 'bicycle mechanic's' technical skill. No mention of the Hebrew context, the specific theology of the Psalter, or the historical reality of Israel. The exegesis is replaced by psychological 'maturity' and 'rhetoric.'
quotes: The rhetoric is like a large, stately fugue...
It is the same word as in verse 3, 'Turn.' In verse 3 God called us to turn from our illusions.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the actual theological weight of the 'wrath' mentioned in verse 9, rather than softening it into 'shattering self-perception.'

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application attempts to be contemporary by mentioning 'technological environments' and 'market ideology,' but it remains largely in the realm of generalities and political categories rather than the concrete spiritual life of the congregation.
quotes: We now live in a Promethean, technological environment...
liberals and conservatives, gay and straight, citizens and illegal aliens...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond listing political demographics and address how this specific text 'expounds' the hearer's personal mortality today.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon avoids the 'block' structure (first exegesis, then application). It attempts to move between the text and the hearer's world, though the 'exposition' side is thin.
quotes: The news that I announce to you today is that we may dwell in this house of deep shalom...
God expects the inhabitants to accept that life is short and to live accordingly.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Deepen the exposition so that the application feels like a necessary consequence of the text's specific logic rather than an external addition.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present as transience and 'arrogance,' but it is psychologized. Redemption is framed as 'grace' and 'free unconditional love,' but it lacks the sharp Christological focus Dekker demands for the 'redemption' part.
quotes: we live by God’s grace, we live by free unconditional love...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Make the 'misery' more than just a 'short-term life'—address the 'wrath' and 'sin' that the Psalm actually mentions.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon fails significantly here. It explicitly moves toward a 'no qualifier' universalism that removes the seriousness of being lost. Life is presented as a 'safe house' regardless of the 'two ways.'
quotes: This news contradicts the market ideology all around us that requires us to qualify.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Reintroduce the 'narrow way' and the possibility of 'temporal loss' (failing God's calling) which the Psalm implies in its plea for 'wisdom of heart.'

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned only as a secondary reference to Luther and the Gospel reading. He is not the 'telos' of the sermon's movement. The sermon is more 'Theocentric' in a general sense than 'Christocentric.'
quotes: the great discovery of Martin Luther, that we live by God’s grace...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly show how Christ is the 'dwelling place' (v. 1) for the mortal human, making Him the goal of the proclamation.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 11-12 minutes, the sermon is far too short to achieve the 'breadth' required for 'depth.' It skims three different Bible passages rather than digging into one.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the length to at least 20 minutes by providing rigorous exposition of the Hebrew text of Psalm 90.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily due to its lack of textual specificity and insufficient length. It functions more as a thematic reflection on 'shalom' and 'grace' than an exposition of Psalm 90. It avoids the 'two ways' by emphasizing a universalist safety that lacks the existential urgency Dekker demands. The technical 'bicycle mechanic' work (Hebrew/Greek/Context) is entirely absent.
strengths: Interwoven structure that avoids a dry, academic split between then and now.
Clear identification of the 'dialogic' nature of the Psalm (the two 'turns').
weaknesses: Insufficient duration (approx. 11 minutes) prevents theological depth.
Dilution of the specific text by introducing other 'generic' Gospel themes.
Absence of the 'two ways'; it presents a world where no one can be lost.
Lack of technical exegesis of the original language and context.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a brief, topical address that uses a Bible passage as a pretext for general theological and social observations, failing the requirement of being an actualization of a specific Word of God.
